quoteFirst: It was in a perfect downpour of rain at four o'clock in the morning, that réveille had been sounded. And it was in sludge and slush camels and mules were fed and loaded, and horses baited and saddled. By
quoteLast: the army was at length on the march out of camp, our faces set towards a village called Merreh, best indicated upon the maps as Seg or Sheikh el Taib, the latter being the name of a low hill. The distance the force was expected to trudge was about eight miles, but the overflowed land put two miles more on.
title: Khartoum Campaign, 1898; or the Re-Conquest of the Soudan
author: Burleigh, Bennet, 1840?-1914

title: The Australian Victories in France in 1918
author: Monash, John, Sir, 1865-1931

quoteFirst: Zero hour for the Third Army was fixed at
quoteLast: on September 27th; but as the 3rd Division on the left and the 5th Division on the right would advance along higher ground than the 42nd, it was arranged that the 42nd should not move until these divisions had had time to make good the higher ground on its flanks.
title: The 42nd (East Lancashire) Division 1914-1918
author: Gibbon, Frederick P.

title: The secret spring

quoteLast: the assault was delivered in heavy rain along the whole Corps front, the 156th and 162nd Brigades covering the infantry of the 17th Division, with the 38th Division on the left and the 21st on the right. The division on the left was held up, but the 17th, after fierce fighting, gained their objectives and consolidated a line north and east of Gauche Wood.
title: The History of the 33rd Divisional Artillery, in the War, 1914-1918.
author: Macartney-Filgate, John Victor; Horne, Henry, 1861-1929 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: The attack was to be made at
quoteLast: on the 9th. The tanks were ordered to enter Poelcapelle with the infantry and drive the enemy out of the houses which they still held.
title: A Company of Tanks
author: Watson, William Henry Lowe, 1891-1932

quoteFirst: However, it was an improvement upon the previous day’s travelling. The only other trains by which we could have gone from Toulouse to Pau were two,—one which left at midnight, getting in at 10 o’clock next morning; and another which left at
quoteLast: , getting to Pau at half–past 1. I mention these facts just to show that every consideration is not paid here, and elsewhere (and it is better here than elsewhere) on French lines, to the convenience of travellers.
title:
Wintering in the Riviera
With Notes of Travel in Italy and France, and Practical Hints to Travellers
author: Miller, William James, 1850-
